title: High drama at botanic gardens
text:
Wednesday, 1 February 2017 High drama at botanic gardens 
JOGGERS stopped in their tracks when a ‘man’ suddenly collapsed at Penang Botanic Gardens, prompting staff members to rush to access his situation. 
While some rushed to contact 999 and retrieve the automated external defibrillator (AED), one started performing cardio-pulmonary resuscitation (CPR) on the ‘victim’ when he stopped breathing. 
The ‘patient’ was a dummy used during a drill conducted by Penang Heart Safe Pro-gramme Task Force to gauge the emergency response time for medical aid. 
During the drill for ‘Sudden Cardiac Arrest’ which was completed in about half an hour, the staff members from Botanic Gardens performed chest compressions with the rate of 100 to 120 times per minute and attached the AED pads on the dummy’s chest once it was ready to be used. A Penang Botanic Gardens staff member retrieving the AED in response to the emergency situation. 
The ambulance arrived 15 minutes after they received the call and the medical personnel took over the resuscitation of the ‘patient’ from the staff member before sending him to hospital. 
Task force chairman Dr Luah Lean Wah said Penang Botanic Gardens was one of the ‘hot spots’ with a record of one collapse reported every few months. 
“Sudden cardiac arrests can also happen to normal healthy people. 
“If emergency life-saving skills (such as CPR) are not performed within four minutes, the patient risks brain damage and brain death,” she said recently. 
Penang Botanic Gardens general worker V. Sivakumaran, who had been working there for the past 11 years, said he had encountered three people who collapsed last year. 
“This is a basic emergency response but if we could provide immediate aid on spot, even if it is a minute earlier, this could make a difference between life and death,” he said.
